The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Foreign Affairs (W.P.(40)481) on the questionwhether the assembly and manufacture of civil and military aircraft for China should be permitted in India or Burma.The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs explained that thefactory at Loiwing, in Yunnan, had already been bombed. The real question was whether to permit this factory, which was run underthe auspices of an American company, to be established in India.The factory would assemble material coming from the United Statesof America and already ordered by the Chinese Government, andwould not, therefore, interfere with our own aircraft programmes.The general view of the War Cabinet favoured this proposal,notwithstanding the risk, to which the Secretary of State for theColonies drew attention, that it would increase bad feeling between this country and Japan.The War Cabinet-Approved the proposals set out in paragraph 14 of theSecretary of State's Memorandum, which may be sum-marised as follows : (1) The machinery from the factory at Loiwing could be moved to a site in India for the manufacture orassembly of aircraft for the Chinese Government.(2) The export to China of military and civil aircraft from india or Burma should be permitted, provided that military aircraft were not in a condition to engage in hostilities when en route to China.(3) The assembly, but not the manufacture, in Burma ofcivil or military aircraft, and their export to China,should be permitted.(4) Chinese pilots should be allowed to enter British terri-tory in order to fly aircraft thence into China.Royal Air Rorce.Pre-EntryTraining.Formation ofAir TrainingCorps.3. The War Cabinet had before them a Memorandum by theSecretary of State for Air (W.P. (40) 480) proposing improved and extended arrangements for pre-entry training for the Royal AirForce.The Secretary of State for Air explained the arrangements which would obtain under his scheme at the universities, the public[22052]b 2 schools, the secondary schools and other schools. In addition tothese, his scheme would provide pre-entry training for young menwho had already entered industry. This part of the scheme wouldbe drawn up in consultation with the Minister of Labour.Broadly speaking, the object of the pre entry scheme was toprepare for Air Force Service boys and young men from the age of15 upwards, who were not at present up to the educational require-ments.In view of the prospect of heavy casualties in the 1941 and 1942campaigns, it was inevitable that a long waiting list for entry intothe Royal Air Force should be maintained.The First Lord of the Admiralty referred to the arrangement made in regard to university candidates for the Fleet Air Arm.He asked that a corresponding arrangement should be made inregard to non-university candidates produced by the present schemewho wished to enter the Fleet Air Arm.The Secretary of State for Air undertook to consider this point.The War Cabinet Approved in principle the scheme outlined in W.P. (40) 480for the creation of an air training corps on as wide a basis as possible, for the provision of pre-entry training foryouths who intend to join the Royal Air Force as air crewsor technicians.Naval, Militaryand air operations.(previous reference:W.M. The Chiefs of Staff reported as follows : The large-scale operation against Mannheim on the night of theIQth December was thought to have given excellent results. About100 tons of high explosive had been dropped and 14,000 incendiary bombs. Extensive fires had been caused, some of which were still burning when a second operation had been undertaken againstMannheim on the night of the 17th December. There had been afurther small attack on the night of the 18th December.The operation on the night of the 16th December would havebeen on an even larger scale if fog had not been forecast.Egypt and The recent air fighting in Libya had been extremely satisfac-Libya. factory. Submarine Truant had reported that she had sunk one,and possibly a second, loaded merchant ship off Cape Spartivento onthe night of the 13th/14th December, and on the night of the15th/16th a south-bound tanker off Cape Colonne.H.M. Submarine Triton and the Free French Submarine Narvalwere overdue. It must be assumed that they were lost.Enemy attacks on shipping included the torpedoing of theBritish steamer Napier Star and the Dutch Tanker Pendrecht.Both vessels were still afloat.The position at Bardia was developing slowly and favourably.At Sidi Omar about 800 prisoners and a battery had been taken.The total British and Imperial casualties reported from the begin-ning of the advance up to the 16th December had amounted to72 killed and 738 wounded.The number of prisoners of war taken was mounting steadily.Up to date some 31,500 had been received into prison camps. Therewere more to come.Heavy snow and severe weather conditions continued, but the greeks had made small advances. In reply to a question, the Chiefof the Imperial General Staff said that the War Office were examin-ing the possibility of sending warm clothing, &c, for the Greeks.Some had already been sent.A successful raid had been carried out on El Wak (90 miles north-East of Wajir). At least 25 Italians and 50 ColonialInfantry, with 3 guns, some machine guns, and a large quantity of stores and ammunition, had been captured. Fifty of the enemy hadbeen killed. Our casualties had been slight.The War Cabinet took note of the above statements.Air Raids. 5.
